title-group.article-title: Endovascular Management of Anastomotic Blowout of Proper Hepatic to Common Hepatic Artery Saphenous Vein Bypass With Coil Embolization and Hepatic Artery Stent Placement

article-meta.aff: 1Boston University Medical Center, Boston, MA, USA

author-notes.corresp: Vijay Ramalingam, Boston University Medical Center, 820 Harrison Ave, FGH Building, Boston, MA 02118, USA. Email: vijay.ramalingam@bmc.org

abstract.p: Mesenteric and visceral artery pseudoaneurysms in the abdomen are a relatively rare complication after abdominal surgery. It is a complication primarily associated with pancreatic and hepatobiliary surgery, trauma, iatrogenic causes and inflammatory diseases. Regardless of etiology, visceral artery pseudoaneurysms of the abdomen reportedly occur only in 0.01% to 2% of the population. Although rare, these are associated with life-threatening bleeding complications and need to be appropriately managed. We present the case of a patient who presented with bleeding after developing a pseudoaneurysm at the distal anastomotic site of a common hepatic to proper hepatic artery interposition saphenous vein bypass that was subsequently excluded by coil embolization and stent graft placement.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: This is a case of a 75 year-old female with a history of gastric cancer initially diagnosed by computed tomography (CT) scan and upper endoscopy in August 2010. In September 2010, the patient underwent diagnostic laparoscopy, gastrojejunostomy, lymphnode dissection and subsequently began chemotherapy. In March 2011, the patient had a laparoscopic radical gastrectomy with lymph node dissection at which time the tumor was found to have entered into the first part of the duodenum and a cholecystectomy was performed during the tumor resection. The procedure was complicated by injury to the common bile duct (CBD) and transection of the common hepatic artery during resection of the tumor. The gastroduodenal artery was divided with clips. The CBD was drained via 14F T-tube placement. The gastroduodenal artery was ligated and a proper hepatic artery to common hepatic artery interposition saphenous vein bypass was performed.

caption.p: Maximum intensity projection image (MIP) image from computed tomography angiogram of the abdomen demonstrating a distal anastomotic pseudoaneurysm (arrow) of the common hepatic to proper hepatic interposition saphenous vein bypass graft.

sec.p: The patient did well postoperatively and was discharged home on day 8. Fifteen days after the procedure, the patient began to have episodes of hematobilia associated with bright red blood per rectum and hypotension, which required readmission and resuscitation with vasopressor therapy and intubation. A bedside esophagogastroduodenoscopy demonstrated thrombus within the stomach with no evidence of active bleeding. The patient had a CT angiogram performed which demonstrated an anastomotic pseudoaneurysm at the distal aspect of the bypass graft (Figure 1). The patient subsequently had an abdominal angiogram performed via right common femoral arterial access with a 4F pigtail catheter. The angiogram demonstrated a patent abdominal aorta, patent superior mesenteric artery, and patent celiac artery. Selective mesenteric angiogram was performed via a 4F C1 Cobra catheter which showed the superior mesenteric artery and vein as well as portal vein to be patent. Next, the celiac trunk was cannulated and a selective splenic angiogram showed the splenic artery, splenic vein, and portal vein to be widely patent. Following evaluation of these images , a selective hepatic arterial angiogram was performed, which demonstrated a large pseudoaneurysm of the distal anastomosis of the anastomotic graft. (Figure 2). At this point, a Renegade microcatheter (Boston Scientific, Natick, Massachusetts) with a 0.014-in Transend wire (Boston Scientific) was advanced into the common hepatic artery after removal of the glidewire and placed just proximal to the pseudoaneurysm. Two 8 mm × 20 cm interlock 2D coils (Boston Scientific) were placed into the pseudoaneurysm and a postprocedure angiogram was obtained, which demonstrated no contrast opacification of the pseudoaneurysm and a patent saphenous vein interposition graft (Figure 3). The patient’s symptoms subsequently resolved with no hematemesis, and she was eventually discharged from the hospital with no subsequent episodes of bleeding, tolerating a normal diet and with normal liver function tests.

caption.p: Digital subtraction angiogram obtained from the common hepatic artery demonstrates a focus of arterial blush (arrow) at the arterial anastomosis of the saphenous vein interposition graft.
Selective digital subtraction angiogram image demonstrates a postembolization angiogram of the coiled anastomotic interposition graft pseudoaneurysm.

sec.p: Approximately 17 days after the coil embolization, the patient returned to the hospital with an episode of hematemesis and was found to have elevated liver function values of alanine transaminase 444, aspartate aminotransferase 798, and alkaline phosphatase 330. The patient was subsequently brought to the angiography suite, and under ultrasound guidance the left brachial artery was accessed. A 5F MPA catheter (Terumo Corporation, Tokyo, Japan) was advanced over the guidewire, and the celiac axis was selectively cannulated. A 0.035 in angled glidewire (Terumo Corporation) was advanced into the right hepatic artery. The 5F sheath was exchanged for a 6F sheath (Cook Medical Inc, Bloomington, Indiana), which was advanced over the wire into the common hepatic artery. A hepatic angiogram was obtained by injecting contrast through the sheath, which showed a recurrent pseudoaneurysm at the distal anastomosis of the saphenous vein interposition graft (Figure 4). A 5 × 22 mm iCast stent (Atrium, Hudson, New Hampshire) was then advanced over the wire and deployed across the distal aspect of the anastomosis to exclude the pseudoaneurysm. The post-stent angiogram showed hepatic artery stent patency with exclusion of the pseudoaneurysm. The post-stenting angiogram showed good opacification of the hepatic artery stent with a lack of opacification of the pseudoaneurysm (Figure 4). The left hepatic artery origin was occluded by the covered stent graft. However, the distal left hepatic artery and its branches were filling form the intrahepatic collaterals.

caption.p: Image on the left demonstrates a persistent focus of contrast blush (arrow), which was determined to be a blowout of the hepatic artery interposition graft. Subsequently, a balloon expandable covered stent graft (arrow) was placed across the origin of the pseudoaneurysm. Post-stent graft angiogram demonstrated exclusion of the anastomotic pseudoaneurysm.

sec.p: Over the next several months, the patient was seen in the surgical clinic for routine follow-up and had multiple unrelated inpatient admissions. During this time, there were no known associated complications with the stent and no evidence for intraabdominal infection or hemorrhage. The patient had a contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen during one of her inpatient admissions approximately 3 months after the original procedure which demonstrated stent graft patency and no evidence for surrounding inflammatory change.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: One of the most common complications after pancreatic and hepatobiliary surgery is bleeding. 1,2 Hepatic artery pseudoaneurysms are frequently iatrogenic. They present with hematobilia, hematemesis, and hematochezia.3 ,4 Hepatic artery pseudoaneurysms are one of the most common types of visceral artery pseudoaneurysms and also appear to be increasing in incidence. Mesenteric anastomotic disruptions are a relatively rare condition that can be the result of infection, trauma, or technical complications from hepatobiliary and pancreatic interventions.5 -7 The associated complications can be morbid and life threatening. Surgical intervention is one option for the treatment of pseudoaneurysms of the visceral arteries; however, the risk of post-operative complications in this patient population can increase the chance of a poor surgical outcome. 8 This is the first reported case describing the endovascular management of a common hepatic to proper hepatic artery saphenous vein interposition graft anastomotic blowout. Transcatheter embolization or stent placement offers a viable treatment alternative to traditional surgery. 9 Although angiography is considered the gold standard evaluation, multidetector CT angiography is a good alternative to making the diagnosis of visceral artery pseudoaneurysms. 3,10 Endovascular options offer the ability to diagnose and treat the condition in high-risk surgical patients with an expected lower complication rate and higher success rate than traditional surgical intervention. 4,11,12 In this case, the pseudoaneurysm was unsuccessfully embolized. It was difficult to completely embolize the pseudoaneurysm without risking distal migration of the embolic coils into the hepatic arterial circulation. It was decided to place a covered stent graft across the pseudoaneurysm sac to exclude the pseudoaneurysm. There are multiple reports about the use of stent graft placement for exclusion of hepatic artery pseudoaneurysms in patients who underwent liver transplant. 3,9,13 –15 However, outside of this population, there is still very little long-term data available on the use of stent graft placement for the exclusion of pseudoaneurysms from the hepatic artery. The case that we are reporting presents an example of a critically ill postoperative patient who was successfully treated using a stent graft to exclude a anastomotic pseudoaneurysm without any complication.
